options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Lectures were recorded.
Lectures were also recorded.
Lectures were recorded.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Commutative algebra + some very basic algebraic geometry at the end.

I learned a good deal of commutative algebra and category theory, and a very small amount of algebraic geometry. More generally I improved my ability to think and reason very abstractly, and I feel like I have a slightly better sense of how mathematics is done in general.
Commutative algebra, Intro to Category theory, Intro to Algebraic Geometry, Various ways to construct rings etc..
Introductory concepts in commutative algebra, a bit of categorical language, some algebraic geometry towards the end.
I learned a bunch of ring theory, and some category theory and basic algebraic geometry.
This course is a whirlwind through advanced topics in abstract algebra, building off of ring theory and running all the way through category theory. Very interesting stuff.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The lectures were very clear, and I think the material selection was very good; I didn't feel like we were doing anything just for the sake of doing it - as many of the ideas are essential.

Weaknesses: This might be a weakness of me and not the course, but I feel like I still don't understand some of the material we covered at a very deep and intuitive level, as the pace was quite fast.

Strength: the problem sets were very well designed and probably ended up being responsible for ~85% of the actual learning. Also the instructor was very good.
Weakness: I actually thought that doing commutative algebra and category theory in a single course worked fine, but the algebraic geometry portion somehow felt unmotivated even though it was supposed to be the application of the material we learned up to that point. I would also say that more intuition/examples can never really hurt.
Professor Loseu's lectures are very clear and his psets solidify your understanding of the material. He pauses frequently to give students opportunities to  collect their thoughts and ask questions.
Strengths: Lectures were extremely clear and well-organized. Grading was timely, and comments on assignments were helpful. I can't think of any weaknesses.
Overall a very solid course. My one complaint is that sometimes I felt like I would've benefitted from more examples for certain concept/definitions when trying to understand them.

The lectures were clear and well-paced, despite the large amount of material to cover. The homework was time-consuming but not unreasonable, and generally involved interesting extensions or examples of what we saw in class. If I had to change something, I'd want more time to be spent discussing tensor products, perhaps focusing more on specific examples; that was by far the most confusing part of the course for me.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I found that recording the lectures and posting lecture notes was really helpful, even if I did attend the class. Some of the material in the class was difficult to digest, so rewatching the lectures or reading over lecture notes was a must.

This course was adapted well to learning during the pandemic. Zoom lectures and office hours were well done, and I appreciated being able to get extensions on problem sets given that being inside all the time made it tough to focus and manage a high workload.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This is certainly a higher-workload class, but I would still recommend it if you want to come through with a good understanding of commutative algebra. It takes a more categorical approach, so you will end up seeing things that you might have already seen in the language of category theory and how it all fits together. The material here is essential for anyone who wants to dig deeper in algebra. I'd say the problem sets certainly took a lot of work, but if you're willing to put in the hours, it is definitely worth it to do so.
Yes, but you have to be willing and able to bridge the gap between knowing about a concept or definition, and understanding/being able to reason about it.
If you didn't like prior algebra courses, I doubt 380 would change your mind - but if you did enjoy them, then absolutely.
Absolutely!
Yes
Absolutely, if they are interested in algebra.
Yes, it was a solid course all around. Good lectures, interesting content, homework that helped me understand concepts without being excessively difficult.

This is one of those classes where if you already want to take it then you certainly should, but otherwise probably not. The course deals with a lot of abstract concepts, which are sometimes hard to nail down. If you liked abstract algebra, it's like that but more so. Abstract algebra is my favorite area of mathematics, so I definitely enjoyed this class; take from that what you will.
